docs.lead_paragraph: Date night, they called this State of the Union address. Here was a chance for a large and unruly freshman class to make a good first impression, for jaded seniors to hold hands across the aisle, and for the skinny president to prove he's more than a nerdy know-it-all.
docs.abstract: If the State of the Union address lacked a certain magic, what will last into the 2012 election and beyond are the governing principles laid out by the two parties.
docs.snippet: If the State of the Union address lacked a certain magic, what will last into the 2012 election and beyond are the governing principles laid out by the two parties.

docs.lead_paragraph: Tiger Woods, Chris Canty (a defensive tackle for the New York Giants) and the Phillies' pitcher Cliff Lee have in the past year or so greatly boosted the popularity of a controversial therapy by employing it to combat a sore knee (Woods), hamstring (Canty) and abdomen (Lee). The treatment, platelet-rich plasma therapy, or P.R.P., involves centrifuging a person's own blood until it contains a concentrated mix of plasma cells and growth factors and then injecting the resulting substance directly into the injured tissue. In theory, the distilled growth factors (a protein or substance that helps stimulate growth) should speed healing and improve the tissue's health, which has happened in the lab. When scientists surgically created lesions in animal tendons and other tissues, P.R.P. therapy nudged the injured tissues to rapidly create new collagen and blood vessels. Meanwhile, testimonials from professional athletes suggested that the shots work in humans as well. Today, recreational athletes reportedly clamor for P.R.P. to treat everything from tennis elbow to back pain, even though the procedure rarely is covered by insurance and can cost $1,000 a shot. "It has buzz," said Dennis Cardone, a clinical associate professor at New York University's Langone Medical Center who has written about the use of P.R.P. in sports medicine.

headline.main: Phys Ed: Does Platelet-Rich Plasma Therapy Really Work?

docs.abstract: Recent studies cast doubt on whether platelet-rich plasma therapy - the expensive and controversial treatment known as P.R.P. - actually helps in the recovery of sports injuries.
docs.snippet: Recent studies cast doubt on whether platelet-rich plasma therapy - the expensive and controversial treatment known as P.R.P. - actually helps in the recovery of sports injuries.

docs.lead_paragraph: Date night, they called this State of the Union address. Here was a chance for a large and unruly freshman class to make a good first impression, for jaded seniors to hold hands across the aisle, and for the skinny president to prove he's more than a nerdy know-it-all. The grumpy grown-ups -- Harry Reid, cautioning against playing too nice, and Mitch McConnell, still sucking on that lemon after he declared his party's agenda was to deprive the president of a second term -- seemed annoyed with it all.
docs.abstract: Timothy Egan Op-Ed column holds that even if Pres Obama's State of the Union address lacked a certain magic, it made lasting impact by clearly laying out governing principles of the nation's two political parties; holds that if Democrats' pragmatic progressive focus prevails, Republicans will have to come up with plan that does more than slash, cut and deny dreams (M)

docs.lead_paragraph: President Obama delivered his second State of the Union address on Tuesday tonight. He focused on five major themes - innovation in energy and technology, improving education, building better infrastructure, reforming government and reducing deficits - all of which were wrapped in the larger idea of increasing America's competitiveness in the world.

docs.lead_paragraph: The Thread has lined up a number of Opinionator columnists and guest experts to weigh in over the course of the State of the Union message this evening, with breaking updates throughout. And, as always on the Thread, we'll be rounding up the most interesting opinions to be found around the blogosphere before, during and after the speech.
docs.abstract: Before, during and after the State of the Union address, The Thread scans commentary from across the Web and hosts responses from guest contributors.

docs.lead_paragraph: Was last year's health care reform the final stitch needed to secure America's social safety net? Jim Kessler, vice president for Third Way, has given an emphatic 'yes,' but Lane Kenworthy, a University of Arizona professor who studies inequality, begs to differ.

headline.main: Expanding, or Maybe Shrinking, the Social Safety Net

docs.abstract: On the perverse dual legacy of the Great Recession.
docs.snippet: On the perverse dual legacy of the Great Recession.

docs.lead_paragraph: The National Academy of Sciences has just released a fascinating report on life expectancy in rich countries around the world. The researchers who wrote the report -- public-health experts, demographers, economists and others, from around the world -- have tried to figure out why Americans don't live as long as people in many other countries.
docs.abstract: A new National Academy of Sciences report names smoking and lack of universal health insurance. Obesity and inequality are also mentioned as possibilities.
docs.snippet: A new National Academy of Sciences report names smoking and lack of universal health insurance. Obesity and inequality are also mentioned as possibilities.
